transcript:
Patient: I did notice some patterns in my negative thoughts. A lot of them seem to revolve around feeling inadequate or like I'm not doing enough. It's like I have this unrealistic standard for myself, and when I inevitably fall short, I get really down on myself.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Jamie. Recognizing those patterns is an important step in challenging and reframing those negative thoughts. It's common for people to have unrealistic standards for themselves, and when we inevitably fall short, it can lead to feelings of inadequacy and self-criticism. This ties into the concept of cognitive distortions, which are irrational or exaggerated thought patterns that can contribute to negative emotions.

One cognitive distortion that might be at play here is "all-or-nothing thinking," where you see things in black-and-white terms without acknowledging the shades of gray in between. For example, if you're not perfect, you might see yourself as a failure, without recognizing all the progress and accomplishments in between those extremes.

Another distortion that might be relevant is "should statements," where you have rigid rules for yourself and feel guilty or inadequate when you don't meet those standards. For example, "I should always be productive and successful, and if I'm not, I'm worthless."

Does any of that resonate with you?

Patient: Absolutely. I definitely fall into that all-or-nothing thinking trap a lot. And I put a lot of pressure on myself with those "should statements." It's like I have this constant inner critic that's never satisfied, no matter how much I achieve.

Therapist: That inner critic can be really loud and persistent, and it's easy to get caught up in those negative thought patterns. But the good news is that you're starting to recognize those distortions, which is the first step in challenging them. As we continue to practice cognitive restructuring, you'll get better at catching those distorted thoughts and reframing them in a more balanced and compassionate way.

Speaking of self-compassion, how did you find the experience of building your self-compassion toolkit with go-to phrases for common triggering situations?

Patient: It was helpful to have those phrases ready when I caught myself being self-critical. One that really resonated with me was, "I am doing the best I can in this moment, and that is enough." It's a reminder to be kind to myself and acknowledge my efforts, even if the outcome isn't perfect.

Therapist: That's a beautiful phrase, and it's so true. Recognizing that you're doing the best you can in any given moment is a powerful way to practice self-compassion. It's about accepting yourself as you are, imperfections and all, and treating yourself with the same kindness and understanding you would offer a good friend.

As we continue to build your self-compassion toolkit, it can be helpful to have a variety of phrases or mantras that resonate with you. You might even consider writing them down on coping cards that you can carry with you or place in strategic locations (like on your mirror or fridge) as reminders throughout the day.

Patient: That's a great idea. I could definitely use those visual reminders, especially on days when I'm feeling really down.

Therapist: Exactly. Having those tangible reminders can be really helpful in moments when it's hard to access self-compassionate thoughts on your own. And as you continue to practice self-compassion, it will start to feel more natural and automatic, even on the tougher days.

Speaking of tough days, you mentioned earlier that you wanted to discuss strategies for staying motivated to practice these techniques when you're feeling really low. Can you tell me more about what those low days look like for you and what gets in the way of practicing self-care and self-compassion?
